quoteFirst: April.  The telegram arrived
quoteLast: in the morning of the 28th April.  Before daylight, the ball-room was unrigged, the decorations were taken down, 300 guests were put off by telegram, and we were steaming at full speed to the _Seignelay_, distant 270 miles.
title: The Memoirs of Admiral Lord Beresford
author: Beresford, Charles William De la Poer Beresford, Baron, 1846-1919

quoteFirst: "Well, I for
quoteLast: getting discouraged," said Mr. Denton. "There's that boy of mine, Jim; how is he repaying my efforts?"
title: For Gold or Soul? The Story of a Great Department Store
author: Sheldon, Lurana, 1862-1945

quoteFirst: Trial follows trial with great rapidity. Gradually the crowd in the court-room thins out. By
quoteLast: only a dozen or fifteen witnesses and spectators remain, and by half-past three the benches are practically empty. "O.C." has heard a dozen different complaining witnesses tell the story of how as many defendants have wronged them.
title: The Prisoner at the Bar: Sidelights on the Administration of Criminal Justice
author: Train, Arthur Cheney, 1875-1945

quoteFirst: So
quoteLast: he turned off the lights and went into his own room.
title: The Business of Life

quoteFirst: _The time is
quoteLast: on the last Saturday in April. A painting of old John Whitworth is over the fireplace._
title: Three Lancashire Plays: The Game; The Northerners; Zack
author: Brighouse, Harold, 1882-1958

quoteFirst: On the 6th of October their Majesties attended a hunting-party which the Grand Duke of Weimar prepared for them in the forest of Ettersbourg.  The Emperor set out from Erfurt at noon, with the Emperor of Russia in the same coach.  They arrived in the forest
quoteLast: , and found prepared for them a hunting-pavilion, which had been erected expressly for this occasion, and was very handsomely decorated.  This pavilion was divided into three parts, separated by open columns; that in the middle, raised higher than the others, formed a pretty room, arranged and furnished for the two Emperors.
title: Recollections of the Private Life of Napoleon — Volume 06
author: Wairy, Louis Constant, 1778-1845; Clark, Walter, 1846-1924 [Translator]

quoteFirst: Carteret about Hater, and shall have him released to-morrow, upon my giving bail for his appearance, which I have promised to do. Sir G. Carteret did go on purpose to the King to ask this, and it was granted. So home at past 12, almost
quoteLast: in the morning. To my office till past two, and then home to supper and to bed.
title: The Diary of Samuel Pepys — Complete
author: Pepys, Samuel, 1633-1703; Braybrooke, Richard Griffin, Baron, 1783-1858 [Editor]; Wheatley, Henry B. (Henry Benjamin), 1838-1917 [Editor]; Bright, Mynors, 1818-1883 [Translator]

quoteFirst: THURSDAY, March 11. My dear aged mother passes away from earth to-day,
quoteLast: . She has been a good mother. I rejoice in the thought that from her bright home in heaven, if saints are permitted to look down upon earth, she can still witness the fruits of her good example and influence, manifest in the well-doing of all her children, and most of her grandchildren.
title:
Life and Labors of Elder John Kline, the Martyr Missionary
Collated from his Diary by Benjamin Funk
author: Kline, John, 1797-1864; Funk, Benjamin, 1829-1909 [Editor]

quoteFirst: “They’ve got a number of tents erected already, and they began blasting operations
title: Young Lord Stranleigh: A Novel
author: Barr, Robert, 1850-1912; Flagg, James Montgomery, 1877-1960 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Captain O'Connell, of the 1st West India Regiment, received the command and a wound almost at the same time; however, the last circumstance could not induce him to give up the honour of the first, and he continued on the field animating his men and resisting the repeated charges of the enemy until about
quoteLast: , when he obliged them to retire from their position with great slaughter. It is impossible for me to do justice to the merit of that officer; you will, I doubt not, favourably report his conduct to His Majesty, and at the same time that of Captain James of the 46th Regiment, and Captain Archibald Campbell, who commanded the grenadiers of that corps.
title: The History of the First West India Regiment
author: Ellis, A. B. (Alfred Burdon), 1852-1894

quoteFirst: The day was exceedingly hot, but we got some shooting to make up for it. We crossed the river in a crazy ferry, found some men, and later on a boat, and reached the famous village of Žabljak about
quoteLast: . The village is still overlooked by a formidable fortress, but in the rude collection of huts it was hard to see the ancient capital of Montenegro, the home of the famous Black Prince dynasty.
title: The Land of the Black Mountain: The Adventures of Two Englishmen in Montenegro
author: Wyon, Reginald, 1872-1921; Prance, Gerald

quoteFirst: Both being eager to get back to our work after breakfast, neither of us referred to the dirty dishes, and I did not remember them again until dinner time. Tom got into a tangle with our heroine about
quoteLast: , and said he would get the lunch by way of relaxation. I presume he relaxed sufficiently without attending to the plates.
title: The Van Dwellers: A Strenuous Quest for a Home
author: Paine, Albert Bigelow, 1861-1937

quoteFirst: Twice in the course of the day Gerásim went stealthily to his captive; and when night came, he lay down to sleep in her company, in the little room, not in the hay-barn, and only
quoteLast: did he go out to take a stroll with her in the fresh air. Having walked quite a long time with her in the courtyard, he was preparing to return, when suddenly a noise resounded outside the fence in the direction of the alley.
title: The diary of a superfluous man, and other stories
author: Turgenev, Ivan Sergeevich, 1818-1883; Hapgood, Isabel Florence, 1850-1928 [Translator]

title: The Companions of Jehu

quoteFirst: The Prince and his guards occupied a knoll at the rear, from which the whole action of the fight was visible. His horse was later covered with mud from the cannon balls striking the wet moor, and a man was killed behind him. By
quoteLast: the Hanoverian army was drawn up within five hundred paces of their enemies. The fifteen regiments of foot were placed in three lines, so arranged that the gaps in the first line were covered by the centres of the regiments in the second line.
title: The Red True Story Book
author: Lang, Andrew, 1844-1912 [Editor]; Ford, H. J. (Henry Justice), 1860-1941 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: But May 14 passed without especial event. Then,
quoteLast: noon of May 15, in a little box canyon there was sudden excitement among the cavalry ahead of the Monach pack-train. Jimmie, first in line at one side behind the “bell,” saw the Indian runner dart down the slope, into the trail, and hand a note to the general.
title:
General Crook and the Fighting Apaches
Treating Also of the Part Borne by Jimmie Dunn in the days, 1871-1886, When With Soldiers and Pack-trains and Indian Scouts, but Employing the Stronger Weapons of Kindness, Firmness and Honesty, the Gray Fox Worked Hard to the End That the White Men and the Red Men in the Southwest as in the Northwest Might Better Understand One Another
author: Sabin, Edwin L. (Edwin Legrand), 1870-1952; Stephens, Charles H., 1851-1931 [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Meanwhile Colonel von Massow
quoteLast: renewed the offensive on the much more advanced left wing. Six companies of the 44th Regiment advanced on Fayet, and after firing into them at the shortest range, drove the French from the place.
title: The Franco-German War of 1870-71
author: Moltke, Helmuth, Graf von, 1800-1891; Forbes, Archibald, 1838-1900 [Translator]

quoteFirst: The distance from my camp was thirty-five miles, and I had the rapid Keiskamma River to cross. I marched at
quoteLast: in the morning, with a corps of mounted men, principally composed of the Swellendam Burghers or Yeomanry, under a veteran old Commandant who had made seven Kafir campaigns. My inroad was perfectly successful, and I reached my bivouac at nine the following night, having marched a distance from point to point of 70 miles, exclusive of operations in the bush.
title: The Autobiography of Lieutenant-General Sir Harry Smith, Baronet of Aliwal on the Sutlej, G.C.B.
author: Smith, Harry George Wakelyn, Sir, 1788-1860; Smith, G. C. Moore (George Charles Moore), 1858-1940 [Editor]

title: Apes and Angels
